Title: MetaGPT: Meta Programming for Multi-Agent Collaborative Framework
Authors: Sirui Hong, Xiawu Zheng, Jonathan Chen, Yuheng Cheng, Ceyao Zhang, Zili Wang, Steven Ka Shing Yau, Zijuan Lin, Liyang Zhou, Chenyu Ran, Lingfeng Xiao, Chenglin Wu
Summary: Recently, remarkable progress has been made in automated task-solving through the use of multi-agents driven by large language models (LLMs). However, existing works primarily focuses on simple tasks lacking exploration and investigation in complicated tasks mainly due to the hallucination problem. This kind of hallucination gets amplified infinitely as multiple intelligent agents interact with each other, resulting in failures when tackling complicated problems.Therefore, we introduce MetaGPT, an innovative framework that infuses effective human workflows as a meta programming approach into LLM-driven multi-agent collaboration. In particular, MetaGPT first encodes Standardized Operating Procedures (SOPs) into prompts, fostering structured coordination. And then, it further mandates modular outputs, bestowing agents with domain expertise paralleling human professionals to validate outputs and reduce compounded errors. In this way, MetaGPT leverages the assembly line work model to assign diverse roles to various agents, thus establishing a framework that can effectively and cohesively deconstruct complex multi-agent collaborative problems. Our experiments conducted on collaborative software engineering tasks illustrate MetaGPT's capability in producing comprehensive solutions with higher coherence relative to existing conversational and chat-based multi-agent systems. This underscores the potential of incorporating human domain knowledge into multi-agents, thus opening up novel avenues for grappling with intricate real-world challenges. The GitHub repository of this project is made publicly available on: https://github.com/geekan/MetaGPT

main_contribution.headline: MetaGPT: A Meta Programming Framework for Multi-Agent Collaboration
main_contribution.description: The paper introduces MetaGPT, a novel framework that infuses human workflows into multi-agent collaboration driven by Large Language Models (LLMs). MetaGPT encodes Standardized Operating Procedures (SOPs) into prompts to foster structured coordination among agents. It also mandates modular outputs, allowing agents with domain expertise to validate outputs and reduce compounded errors. By leveraging the assembly line work model, MetaGPT assigns diverse roles to various agents, effectively deconstructing complex multi-agent collaborative problems.

takeaways.headline: MetaGPT offers a structured approach to multi-agent collaboration
takeaways.description: MetaGPT presents a promising approach to tackle complex tasks using multi-agent collaboration driven by LLMs. By encoding SOPs into prompts and mandating modular outputs, it introduces structure and validation into the process, reducing errors and improving coherence. This approach could be particularly useful in domains like software engineering, where tasks can be broken down and assigned to different agents, similar to human roles in an assembly line.
takeaways.example: For instance, in a software development project, MetaGPT could assign different roles to agents: one for requirements analysis, another for system design, and others for coding and testing. Each agent would follow SOPs encoded into prompts and produce modular outputs, which are validated by other agents, ensuring the overall coherence and correctness of the project.

novelty_analysis: The paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent collaboration by introducing MetaGPT, a framework that infuses human workflows into LLM-driven systems. This approach of encoding SOPs into prompts and mandating modular outputs is a significant advancement in the field of multi-agent systems.
technical_analysis: The paper is somewhat technical, discussing the design and implementation of the MetaGPT framework. However, it does not delve into complex mathematical theories or algorithms, making it accessible to readers with a basic understanding of LLMs and multi-agent systems.
enjoyable_analysis: The paper is well-structured and presents an interesting approach to multi-agent collaboration. The use of real-world examples, like software engineering tasks, makes the content relatable and easy to understand, making it an enjoyable read.
